column4: Can I get some help with VirtualBox...I have created a new WindowsXP virtual machine, and given it access to the shared folders on my Secondary Hard Drive (Internal IDE).  When I start the Windows virtual machine, I can access the files on those folders, but I cant write back to them...I am told that either the drive is write-protected or i do not have permissions.  Everything is ok with Linux though?
as fixarg says, sounds like permissions - and make sure the drive itself is mounted read/write for the host OS
: the drive is mounted, as I can see and view the files...i can even access them ok...I just cant seem to right back to the drive (folders and files contained within)
can you write back to files on the drive from Linux?
: yes
if it's an NTFS filesystem it will probably me mounted read-only
: it is NTFS
... but mounted r/w?
: yes....I can write back to that drive ok in linux
hm, don't know then, maybe there's something in the virtualbox docs
: maybe...I will look and see
What exactly are you trying to do?

...hey mate...ahhh well, I have been using grabit in windows, and I started using it in wine, but it gets al ittle flaky from time to time...so before I get home i want to make a decision which way I'm going to download and use nzb files.  I thought about what you said this morning, then read up on updating wine (thinking this was the way forward)...so I'm now at a junction of decision making
I didn't understand much of that
: dont worry about it mate :D
what are nzb files, and why do they need special consideration when downloading?
: nzb files are binary files
so, why do you need special software to download them?
: because the nzb file is a tracker file, which 'points' to the actual files you are trying to download, such a rar files (you should read up on this reallly)
why should I read up on it?
it sounds somewhat related to file sharing
